scenes.label: *start
texts: Oh, but I got some good news! It's real juicy info!
Is it about the post from before?!
But there's something new on 4chan. Look at this.
He sent me some image file.
Flight Plan Garuda. It's a flight simulator.
The package Cross sent me displayed a passenger plane.
Looks like this has something to do with the autopilot going wild.
The other hackers are thinking the same thing. They're guessing that some player's inputs are being used as guidance data.
Meaning our next priority was to find that player.
Momo, I'm goin' out for a sec.
Okay. Leave the repeater to me.
I knew it was a lot for her to dig through alone, but looking into this flight simulator lead could take us right to the flight path.
It was important info we needed to complete the quest.
Leaving Momo, I went outside to reset my thoughts.
Let's both do it. Reverse hacking the source wasn't going too well, so I was trying to come up with Plan B.
Can you get info on the players?
I knew you'd ask. I just hacked into the developer's server; give me a sec and I'll grab the data.
I figured I'd get some info too. I was gonna use a different method, though.
I ran a search for "Garuda" and got an article right away.
It was a US-made sim that was published in the west, but you could buy it anywhere in the world. It had sold about 9,000 copies globally.
I played the video embedded in the article, and saw some actual gameplay.
So you need online verification to start it.
That was a common way to prevent anyone but the buyer from playing games.
The gameplay video showed the menu, then the stage select screen, and then a load screen that lasted about five seconds.
There was text in the bottom-right saying that something was being downloaded.
Here's the list of players. It's linked to their access states, too.
I looked into the stage data as well, but there's nothing about JA1037E or Flight 302. This is about all we can use.
So 274 people went through online verification right before the plane went out of control.
Looking through everyone would take all day.
There was gameplay footage showing something being downloaded after the stage select screen. Probably stage data from the official servers.
But since there's no stage for Flight 302...
Here, I filtered the list to players who didn't download any stages after verification. It's short enough to check manually now.
All right, I'll start from the bottom.
I used the player IDs to trace back to the server logs, keeping an eye out for anything strange.
The first one...was fine. Same with the second.
There was one ID with a completely different log. This guy was clearly playing an unofficial stage.
Swallow Apartments, Room 201. His name's Lime Nukui.
Let's see if we can hack in...
I tried checking whether there was a device in the room that I could slip into.
It'd be faster just to go there. It's like ten minutes away.
Finding the source is my job. You've got other things to take care of.
Then send me the flight path data as soon as you have it. I need it for my drone plan.
All right. I'll get it to ya.
I'm back! You got the repeater?!
I've looked over more than half of what's here, but no luck yet.
I'll see if we can get it elsewhere.
I used the model number to check whether any nearby stores had it in stock.
Expanding the range didn't help, either.
I contacted some local hackers too, but even they were empty-handed. Pretty rare piece of tech, I guess.
Looks like we'll just have to find it here.
I ran the comparison app and resumed the search.
